moves.3... exd4 4. Nxd4 h6: ?! I think this is unnecessary.  Neither Bishop nor knight is going to g5 anytime soon.
moves.5. Nc3 Be7 6. Be3 Nf6 7. Bd3 b6: !? Weakens a6, c6, d5, especially since black never plays Bb7.
moves.8. O-O c5: ? This has to be a strategical error.  It leaves a backward pawn on d6 and weakens the light squares more.
moves.9. Bb5+: Forcing the exchange of bishops, and his was the only defender of the light squares.  I also wanted to clear out the knight and bishop between my queen and his d-pawn.
moves.9... Bd7 10. Nf5: Adding a second attacker onto d6.
moves.10... O-O 11. Nxe7+: I played this because I thought that it would make the attack on d6 easier, and that I wanted to have a bishop over knight advantage, but in retrospect, this seemed like trading an active knight for a bad bishop.
moves.13. Re1: Now if 13...Nxe4 14.Nxe4 Qxe4 Qxd6 and white looks good.
I captured with the queen to create more complications, which are favorable for me because I have more space.
moves.16... Rad8 17. Rad1 Qf6 18. Bg3 Re6: ? Not only does this drop a pawn, but it also just plainly loses time.  I think something like 18...Ng4 is better.
moves.19. f4: ! Thanks to Black's last move, this is quite strong.  The knight can't retreat to g6 because of the fork.
moves.19... Nd7 20. f5: Attacking the misplaced rook while opening a line for the bishop.
moves.20... Re7: ? Much better was Re8, getting the rook off of the dark square.
moves.21. Qxd6 Qxd6: ? Black was lost anyway, but this just drops the exchange.  After 21...Re8 22. Qxf6 gxf6 23. Bh4, black's losing another pawn.
moves.23. Bc7: ! Attacking the rook that defends the knight.  Black loses the exchange and rightfully resigned here.  I hope you enjoyed this game.  BTW, as this is my second annotation and I'm not quite clear on some gameknot terms, how do I use/where do I find the star rating system?
